content.webTitle: Coalition to rule out conservative demands for 'religious freedom' law

fields.headline: Coalition to rule out conservative demands for 'religious freedom' law
fields.bodyText: The government is set to disappoint backbench MPs who have called for a law to protect “religious freedom”, with the attorney general confirming it will present a “basic” bill to prevent discrimination. On Wednesday Christian Porter told Radio National the proposed Religious Discrimination Act will “follow the basic architecture of discrimination bills” by defining religion as a protected attribute. The comments appear to rule out demands for a broader bill to give a positive right to express religious opinions even where they breach employment codes of conduct, as occurred when rugby player Israel Folau claimed on social media that gay people go to hell. Coalition members who have publicly pushed for that option include Kevin Andrews, Concetta Fierravanti-Wells and Barnaby Joyce. But conservative Coalition members have not given up on agitating the issue, citing swings against Labor in some areas with high religious populations as indicating a mood for greater protections. Porter said the Coalition’s plan is to release an “omnibus bill which tidies up a range of issues such as clarifying whether or not in the Charities Act you could be excluded from being a charity for proposing the traditional definition of marriage”. He described the bill as “largely uncontroversial”, despite the fact in December it was described as a bill to provide “equal status” to freedom of religion alongside the right to non-discrimination, which will likely be controversial to LGBTI groups. The government has also referred the issue of religious schools’ exemptions – which allow discrimination against LGBT students and staff – to the Australian Law Reform Commission. Porter said that when parliament resumes in early July or shortly after the government will present a religious discrimination bill that will follow the “very standard architecture of discrimination acts”. “We define an attribute, in this case someone’s religious qualities or indeed irreligious qualities – it will apply to people who don’t believe in religion – and then we say that persons holding those attributes will be protected from certain behaviour in certain circumstances, again, just like the Race or Sex Discrimination Act. “And then the third part of the act will be a range of logical exceptions that you’ll have to have.” Porter said the law would protect people “because of the fact that they hold a particular religious view”. On Tuesday Liberal MP Tim Wilson backed the more limited form of a religious discrimination act which he said would not be “overly controversial” but is “quite different from a religious freedom act”. “And the reality is, freedom of religion includes people of faith and without faith because that’s a legitimate exercise for your freedom of conscious as well, so once you start going down that path of religious freedom act, what you are actually arguing for is a human rights act,” he told the ABC. Wilson said that such a law would “empower bureaucrats and unelected judges to be able to make decisions about the limits of our freedom rather than the parliament and peoples’ natural right to be able to live their life freely”. LGBT rights groups agree in theory that discrimination on the basis of religion should be outlawed but have warned that the law must be a “shield not a sword” against LGBTI people.
